sources.name: 1Password
sources.description: The 1Password source shows credential access and audit logs from your 1Password organization.

sources.name: Abnormal AI
sources.description: Collect logs from your Abnormal AI tenant using an API key.

sources.name: Atlassian
sources.description: Ingest information from your Atlassian account across their entire suite of products.

sources.name: Auth0
sources.description: Collect logs from your Auth0 account.

sources.name: Authentik
sources.description: Ingest authentik audit logs from a variety of sources.

sources.name: AWS ALB
sources.description: Collect logs from your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB).

sources.name: AWS Cloudtrail Logs
sources.description: Monitor the management and data events from a single AWS account or an organization.

sources.name: AWS DNS Logs
sources.description: Collect DNS logs from your AWS account.

sources.name: AWS Flow Logs
sources.description: Collect flow logs from your AWS account.

sources.name: AWS Hosted Zone
sources.description: The AWS Hosted Zone source collects logs from Cloudwatch by polling the Cloudwatch API for changes and access to your hosted zones.

sources.name: AWS Network Firewall
sources.description: Collect AWS Network Firewall logs from S3, including alert, flow (netflow), and TLS revocation events in Suricata EVE JSON format.

sources.name: AWS S3 Access Logs
sources.description: Collect S3 access logs to monitor bucket activity, access patterns, and security events.

sources.name: AWS WAF Logs
sources.description: Collect AWS WAF logs to monitor web application firewall activity, security events, and traffic patterns.

sources.name: Azure Activity Logs
sources.description: Your Azure Activity Logs show management across your Azure resources and subscriptions.

sources.name: Azure Entra Logs
sources.description: The Azure Entra logs source allows you to collect your Azure Active Directory and other identity logs.

sources.name: Azure Flow Logs
sources.description: The network logs from your Azure account can be collected with the Azure Flow Logs source.

sources.name: Backfill
sources.description: Backfill logs you've already collected in a blob storage container. This can take some time

sources.name: Bitwarden
sources.description: Collect audit and event logs from your Bitwarden organization, including user access, item events, and administrative changes.

sources.name: Box
sources.description: Box audit logs that show information about management events and access to your Box resources.

sources.name: CircleCI Audit Logs
sources.description: Collect audit logs from CircleCI showing workflow runs, user actions, and organizational changes.

sources.name: Cloudentity Logs
sources.description: The Cloudentity source shows logs and events from your Cloudentity account.

sources.name: Cloudflare Access Requests
sources.description: The Cloudflare Access Requests logs show authentication and authorization events for users accessing protected applications.

sources.name: Cloudflare Audit Log
sources.description: Cloudflare Audit logs show changes to your Cloudflare account and management information about your Cloudflare account like new certificates issued for your zones.

sources.name: Cloudflare Firewall Logs
sources.description: Cloudflare Firewall Logs provide detailed information about WAF events, security actions, and firewall rules triggered on your domain.

sources.name: Cloudflare Gateway DNS Logs
sources.description: The Cloudflare Gateway DNS product will show the hostnames resolved by your Zero Trust enrolled team-members.

sources.name: Cloudflare Gateway HTTP Logs
sources.description: The Cloudflare Gateway product emits HTTP logs that show you what websites your Zero Trust enrolled team-members are accessing.

sources.name: Cloudflare Gateway Network
sources.description: Cloudflare Zero Trust Network logs show network traffic and security events from your Zero Trust network.

sources.name: Cloudflare HTTP Log
sources.description: Ingest raw HTTP logs from your Cloudflare Zones into RunReveal.

sources.name: Cloudflare R2 Generic Source
sources.description: Ingest line delimited json and compressed json logs from Cloudflare's R2 blob storage.

sources.name: CrowdStrike
sources.description: Collect logs from your CrowdStrike account. This data is far less detailed than the Falcon Data Replicator source and we read it from the CrowdStrike API.

sources.name: CrowdStrike Falcon Data Replicator
sources.description: The CrowdStrike Falcon Data Replicator source shows agent logs, app related logs, crowdstrike's managed alerts, and raw process data.

sources.name: Cyberhaven Logs
sources.description: The Cyberhaven source shows incident alerts and events from your Cyberhaven account.

sources.name: DNSFilter
sources.description: Ingest the DNS logs from your DNSFilter account. See exactly what domain names are being resolved in your network.

sources.name: Dope Security
sources.description: Ingest Dope Security endpoint protection logs from object storage showing network traffic, file activity, and security events.

sources.name: Dope Security Webhook
sources.description: Ingest Dope Security endpoint protection logs from object storage showing network traffic, file activity, and security events.

sources.name: Dropbox
sources.description: Dropbox audit logs that show information about management events and access to your Dropbox resources.

sources.name: Duo Security
sources.description: Collect authentication logs from your Duo Security account to monitor user authentication events and multi-factor authentication activities.

sources.name: Fastly WAF
sources.description: Collect logs from your Fastly WAF.

sources.name: FireHydrant
sources.description: Collect audit logs from your FireHydrant account to monitor incident management activities, on-call rotation changes, and administrative actions.

sources.name: Formal Security
sources.description: Collect data access logs from Formal Security, including actor, network, and resource information for comprehensive visibility into data access patterns.

sources.name: GCP Logs
sources.description: Collect logs from your GCP projects.

sources.name: Generic Azure Blob
sources.description: Ingest generic information and transform it in real time from Azure Blob storage. Great for any kind of structured logs

sources.name: Generic GCP PubSub
sources.description: Ingest generic information and transform it in real time from GCP PubSub. Great for real-time event processing and high volume log streaming

sources.name: Generic GCS Blob
sources.description: Ingest generic information and transform it in real time from GCS Blob storage. Great for any kind of structured logs

sources.name: Github
sources.description: Your GitHub organization logs about repositories, access changes, updates to your account, and more.

sources.name: Github Webhook Logs
sources.description: The GitHub webhook log source collects only pull-request information like merges and approvals. No other GitHub data is collected with this source.

sources.name: Gitlab
sources.description: Collect details logs about everything happening in your GitLab organization

sources.name: Google Workspace
sources.description: Ingest data from you Google Workspace products like drive, calendar, docs, and more.

sources.name: GuardDuty
sources.description: The AWS GuardDuty source collects findings from AWS GuardDuty. This is a very low volume source, with high fidelity alerts.

sources.name: HashiCorp Vault
sources.description: Collect audit logs from your HashiCorp Vault instance, showing who accessed what secrets, when, and from where.

sources.name: Heroku
sources.description: Collect audit trail events from your Heroku Enterprise account, including app creation, add-on management, collaborator changes, and team membership updates.

sources.name: JAMF Protect
sources.description: Ingest JAMF Protect logs that capture real-time endpoint threat detection, prevention, and remediation from an S3 bucket.

sources.name: JAMF Protect via Webhook
sources.description: Ingest JAMF Protect logs that capture real-time endpoint threat detection, prevention, and remediation from a webhook.

sources.name: JAMF Webhooks
sources.description: Your JAMF webhook information mostly shows locations that your devices have pinged from, and other kinds of management events.

sources.name: JumpCloud
sources.description:
JumpCloud Directory Insights logs capture authentication, authorization, and directory management events across your JumpCloud environment, including user logins, group modifications, system access attempts, and policy changes.
    These logs are crucial for security monitoring, compliance reporting, and understanding user activity across your organization's directory services.

sources.name: Keeper Security
sources.description: Collect logs from your Keeper Security account.

sources.name: Kubernetes Audit Log
sources.description: Collect audit logs from your Kubernetes clusters.

sources.name: Linear Audit Logs
sources.description: Collect audit logs from Linear via webhook to track user actions, team changes, and project modifications.

sources.name: Lumos Logs
sources.description: Ingest Lumos access management and governance logs from object storage.

sources.name: MongoDB
sources.description: Collect logs from your MongoDB account.

sources.name: Notion
sources.description: Receive logs directly from Notion about changes to your workspace, access to your Notion documents, and more.

sources.name: Obsidian Logs
sources.description: We'll receive Obsidian's findings via a webhook so you can save all of their findings for later.

sources.name: Okta
sources.description: Ingest all information emitted by the Okta Audit Logs product. Once set up, we will ingest the previous 30 days of audit logs

sources.name: Opal Logs
sources.description: Receive events from Opal.dev event streaming to monitor access management activities and security events.

sources.name: OpenTelemetry (OTLP)
sources.description: Ingest OpenTelemetry logs that have been uploaded to object storage as JSON.

sources.name: PagerDuty
sources.description: Collect audit logs and events from your PagerDuty account to monitor administrative changes and user activities.

sources.name: Palo Alto Panorama Traffic
sources.description: Collect traffic logs from your Palo Alto Panorama.

sources.name: Reveald
sources.description: The Reveald source is a webhook or bucket source that allows you to ship logs from your endpoints to us.

sources.name: S3 Generic
sources.description: The S3 generic source allows you to ingest just about any kind of log from an S3 bucket, and transform the format in real time..

sources.name: Sentinel One
sources.description: Ingest data from your Sentinel One account about devices in your fleet.

sources.name: SentinelOne Endpoint Logs
sources.description: Ingest SentinelOne endpoint security logs from object storage. Monitor process activities, network connections, and security events.

sources.name: Slack
sources.description: Ingest Slack audit logs that show information about management events and access to your Slack resources.

sources.name: Snowflake
sources.description: Collect login history and authentication events from your Snowflake account.

sources.name: Sophos
sources.description: Collect logs from your Sophos account.

sources.name: Structured Webhook
sources.description: If you want to integrate directly with the RunReveal and send us a small to moderate amount of logs in a format that you've pre-structured then this likely your best option.

sources.name: Tailscale Audit
sources.description: Collect audit logs from your Tailscale tailnet showing changes and administrative events.

sources.name: Tailscale Flow
sources.description: Flow logs from your Tailscale network are pushed to us via a webhook.

sources.name: Teleport Cloud Audit Logs
sources.description: Ingest information from Teleport about what systems are being accessed via Teleport by your team-members.

sources.name: Teleport Cloud Audit Logs via webhook
sources.description: Ingest information from Teleport about what systems are being accessed via Teleport by your team-members. This allows for ingesting logs via webhook, instead of Parquet files pushed to an S3 bucket

sources.name: Twingate Logs
sources.description: Ingest Twingate network access logs, DNS filtering, audit events, and data loss prevention logs from object storage.

sources.name: Webflow
sources.description: Collect audit logs from your Webflow workspace showing user access, content changes, and administrative events.

sources.name: Webhook Generic Logs
sources.description: The generic webhook source allows you to send any kind of log data to us and transform it into structured logs, or store the generic log.

sources.name: Wiz Threats
sources.description: Collect threat alerts and findings from Wiz security platform via webhook.

sources.name: Workday
sources.description: Capture Workday activity logs detailing records of user actions, system events, and data changes within the Workday platform

sources.name: Zendesk
sources.description: Collect information from your Zendesk account about access to your helpdesk and administrative changes
